LPM also shuts down a significant amount of the available CPU, which creates a lot of glitches and sluggish performance in the app. Try to render a project in LPM for instance.

I have noted that you think it would be better if we simply notified users about the downsides of running in LPM instead of explicitly preventing them from using the app. This is valid feedback and something we might have to reconsider.

item.title: Low Power Mode Notification
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
aUstin_Haga:

Lol but look right under that. he says you simply have to…

And I suggest you look at my initial response to that.

It would seem that some here (and presumably beyond) are genuinely being forced to change the way they use their phone, despite everything apparently working well before. I hope that the team will revisit this issue, with those users – and those who share their opinions – in mind, and look again at possible ways to reduce the impact to those users.

In terms of many ideas they’ll have listed, they’ll prioritise based on their own criteria. As always, these things are a balancing act between addressing ‘squeaky wheels’ brought up by users (particularly major negative ones) and still pushing forward with the planned changes.

 
Anyhoo, I thing this horse has been well and truly flogged, so I too will leave it (for now).

item.title: Low Power Mode Notification
item.dc:creator: Produk
item.description:
I don’t know why this is such a big deal. My iPad can run auxy for quite a long time. Why use low power mode?
If your using low power mode during the day, charge your phone the night before so it won’t have to be in low power all day.
Also, I find that turning off background app refresh for most apps saves a lot of battery.

If you want to have auxy run on low power mode, think of it like this:
Would you rather drive a car at 10mph for 5 hours, or 100mph for 2 hours?
Your amount of gas doesn’t change, it just runs out slower(however, you don’t make it as far as fast.)

Give users a choice if they want to us low power mode, but give em a warning about the consequences.

item.title: Low Power Mode Notification
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Db909:

I thought you had to manually enable low power mode

That’s correct. It’s offered when your battery hits a certain low – at 20% and again at 10%.
Of course, you can enable (and disable) it at any point, regardless of remaining battery life.

Apple.com: Use Low Power Mode to extend battery life on your iPhone

Low Power Mode reduces or affects these features:

Email fetch
“Hey Siri”
Background app refresh
Automatic downloads
Some visual effects
Auto-Lock (defaults to 30 seconds)

When Low Power Mode is on, the battery in the status bar will be yellow. You’ll see and the battery percentage. After you charge your iPhone to 80% or higher, Low Power Mode automatically turns off.

Afaik, Auxy has no background features, including playing sound.
This is the first 3rd-party app (with no background processes) that I’ve not encountered that goes beyond what Apple is aiming to do with LPM – i.e. Apple isn’t interfering with you actively using apps, only those processes you aren’t actively using.

Also, does the 80% recharge line quoted above also mean that, if Auxy has effectively shut down while in LPM, it won’t become fully usable again until there’s 80% charge in the phone – or I manually disable LPM?

Would you be equally OK if car manufacturers only allowed you to drive your own car if your gas tank had more than 10% in it?
